content:
This clash is unfair in reverse mode.

The tests makes you think that you have to verify all the bases until base 10000.
But the validators shows that you have to verify all the bases until base 12000.

In reverse mode, we have no way to know that we have to go until 12000.

Correct the validators please. This clash is currently shitty and fuckogenic in reverse mode.

âš ï¸ Changed the contribution : Swapped test 8 & validator 8 so people know there's a lot more bases to test.

Also, maybe reverse should be removed
this was really tough in reverse in terms of getting all the validators and constraints nailed. Might be worth considering toggling that mode.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle , goes well with all the game modes.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, quick to understand and allows multiple approaches.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Description is (now) clear and concise.
Multiple possible way to solve this, some less efficient than others *cough*loop*cough* :)
Not difficult, but made me think "which approach should I use?" (this is a good thing)

"A number N is jackpot in base B" suggests that N is in base B. I don't think that's what you're trying to say.

"every base starts out with the same symbols as decimal" suggests that:
- binary uses 0-9
- hexadecimal uses 0-9
This is just confusing.

Thanks for the comment.

> I don't think that's what you're trying to say.

I added some quotation marks around "a jackpot in base B". Does that help?

> every base starts out with the same symbols as decimal

I changed to "Also assume that the first 10 symbols in the base [[B]] (where [[B]] > 10) are always 0â€“9." Does that help?

If you have a suggestion on how one might word it, would love to hear â€” English isnâ€™t my first languageâ€¦

Thank you for swapping it.

When I created this, I made the output say "A jackpot in base 16" and "Not a jackpot" so that it is playable in Reverse mode.

Without the Reverse Mode in mind, the output would simply say "16" and "0".
My apologies. Thanks ChiefChippy2 for swapping the test & validators. Next time I will make sure validator case is always smaller than test case.

the reason reverse feels like a bad idea is simply because you need to 1 figure out what the code should do and to be honest, it's not that apparent for everyone.
also, maybe you should explain briefly in the statement how the base conversion should work for fastest/shortest mode, but that's up to you.

>I added some quotation marks around "a jackpot in base B". Does that help?

Yes

I don't think you need to specify "Also assume that the first 10 symbols in the base B (where B > 10) are always 0â€“9."
It's like saying "Assume binary uses the digits 0 and 1" or "Assume octal uses the digits 0-7". That's part of the definition of binary/octal, not something that needs to be assumed.

I would also remove the "Assume that there are always enough symbols to represent a number in base B"
Thanks. I reduced the problem statement to a single sentence now. Maybe less words means less confusion ;). Do you think this now looks better?

It's much clearer now. ðŸ™‚

A minor improvement:
I would change 
"...when represented in base B, reads out 777."
to
"...when represented in base B, it reads out 777."
or
"...when represented in base B, it is 777."
Thank you, changed to "it reads out 777".
